post_title: Starmer indicates he will not raise income tax for top earners
comment_body: There is not much scope left for higher taxes in the UK. The burden is already high and contrary to what I read here sometimes the better off already pay a lot more income tax. Getting the actually rich to pay is not easy as they are mobile but that is a whole another story.
comment_argument: the burden is already high and high earners can move

post_title: How poverty rate is higher among immigrants if immigration requires proof of funds/income?
comment_body: The issue is mostly a wealth question a significantly larger proportion of foreign born people are private renters 40 v 15 compared to the UK born who are more likely to be owner occupiers 68 v 48. Were not checking if you have enough money to buy a house, were checking if you have enough money to rent. Poverty rates for foreign born people are similar by tenure to UK born people, but higher for social renters than owner occupiers.
comment_argument: need to consider the high rental rate for the foreign born people
llm_argument: the comment argues that poverty rates among immigrants are not inherently higher due to immigration requiring proof of funds but rather are linked to the fact that immigrants are disproportionately private renters a tenure associated with higher poverty rates regardless of origin it clarifies the check isnt about homeownership ability but about rental affordability

post_title: Lowest graduate salaries ‘on a par with minimum wage’ - The shrinking pay gap raises fears that university may be a waste of money for many students and could turn disaffected young people towards political extremes
comment_body: The other side to this was a downplaying of traditional apprenticeship routes towards achieving a fulfilling career. New Labours Education Education Education policy inevitably devalued apprenticeships, contributing to the housing crisis via increased construction costs. University became merely an extension of 6th form and degrees were subsequently devalued forcing graduates to chase a questionable masters degree or PhD in order to distinguish themselves. Nearly all sweeping centralised policies like this lead to unforeseen consequences.
comment_argument: the university system is the other reason causing this
llm_argument: the comment aligns with the titles concern about devalued degrees and a questionable return on investment for university arguing that policies prioritizing university education diminished the value of alternatives like apprenticeships and ultimately contributed to negative consequences
